pageProps.contentHtml:
conformal mappings

Find an explicit conformal mapping from the upper half-plane slit along the vertical segment,

{z∈C∣Im⁡z>0}∖(0,0+ih],h>0,\set{z \in \C \mid \Im{z} > 0} \setminus \poc{0, 0 + ih}, \quad h > 0,{z∈C∣Imz>0}∖(0,0+ih],h>0,

to the unit disk {z∈C∣∣z∣<1}\set{z \in \C \mid \abs{z} < 1}{z∈C∣∣z∣<1}.
Solution.

Let Ω\OmegaΩ be the domain in question.

First, consider the map φ1(z)=zz−ih\phi_1\p{z} = \frac{z}{z - ih}φ1​(z)=z−ihz​, which is the Möbius transformation which sends 0↦00 \mapsto 00↦0, ih↦∞ih \mapsto \inftyih↦∞, and ∞↦1\infty \mapsto 1∞↦1. Notice that

φ1(1)=11+h2(1+ih)andφ1(−1)=11+h2(−1+ih),\phi_1\p{1} = \frac{1}{1 + h^2}\p{1 + ih} \quad\text{and}\quad \phi_1\p{-1} = \frac{1}{1 + h^2}\p{-1 + ih},φ1​(1)=1+h21​(1+ih)andφ1​(−1)=1+h21​(−1+ih),

so the real line is mapped to the generalized circle containing 0,11+h2(1+ih),11+h2(−1+ih),10, \frac{1}{1 + h^2}\p{1 + ih}, \frac{1}{1 + h^2}\p{-1 + ih}, 10,1+h21​(1+ih),1+h21​(−1+ih),1. By symmetry, this is the circle centered at i2\frac{i}{2}2i​ of radius 12\frac{1}{2}21​. Notice that if t≥0t \geq 0t≥0, then

φ1(it)=itit−ih=tt−h,\phi_1\p{it} = \frac{it}{it - ih} = \frac{t}{t - h},φ1​(it)=it−ihit​=t−ht​,

so the ray (0,ih]\poc{0, ih}(0,ih] is mapped to (0,−∞]\poc{0, -\infty}(0,−∞], and the ray (ih,∞]\poc{ih, \infty}(ih,∞] is mapped to [1,∞]\br{1, \infty}[1,∞]. Hence, φ1\phi_1φ1​ maps Ω\OmegaΩ to Ω1={∣z−i2∣>12}∖(−∞,0)\Omega_1 = \set{\abs{z - \frac{i}{2}} > \frac{1}{2}} \setminus \p{-\infty, 0}Ω1​={∣∣​z−2i​∣∣​>21​}∖(−∞,0). If we let φ2(z)=2(z−i2)\phi_2\p{z} = 2\p{z - \frac{i}{2}}φ2​(z)=2(z−2i​), then φ2∘φ1\phi_2 \circ \phi_1φ2​∘φ1​ maps Ω\OmegaΩ to Ω2={∣z∣>1}∖(−i∞,−i)\Omega_2 = \set{\abs{z} > 1} \setminus \p{-i\infty, -i}Ω2​={∣z∣>1}∖(−i∞,−i), i.e., the exterior of the unit disk with the bottom ray removed.

Let φ3(z)=1z\phi_3\p{z} = \frac{1}{z}φ3​(z)=z1​. Then {∣z∣>1}\set{\abs{z} > 1}{∣z∣>1} is mapped to {∣z∣<1}\set{\abs{z} < 1}{∣z∣<1}, and the ray (−i∞,−i)\p{-i\infty, -i}(−i∞,−i) gets mapped to (0,i)\p{0, i}(0,i), so φ3\phi_3φ3​ maps Ω2\Omega_2Ω2​ conformally to Ω3={∣z∣<1}∖(0,i)\Omega_3 = \set{\abs{z} < 1} \setminus \p{0, i}Ω3​={∣z∣<1}∖(0,i). Let φ4(z)=−i\phi_4\p{z} = -iφ4​(z)=−i, which maps Ω3\Omega_3Ω3​ to Ω4={∣z∣<1}∖(0,1)\Omega_4 = \set{\abs{z} < 1} \setminus \p{0, 1}Ω4​={∣z∣<1}∖(0,1), which is the unit disk with a segment removed.

Let φ5(z)=z\phi_5\p{z} = \sqrt{z}φ5​(z)=z​ where the argument of a number is taken in [0,2π)\pco{0, 2\pi}[0,2π). This maps Ω4\Omega_4Ω4​ to Ω5={∣z∣<1}∩{Im⁡z>0}\Omega_5 = \set{\abs{z} < 1} \cap \set{\Im{z} > 0}Ω5​={∣z∣<1}∩{Imz>0}, which is the upper half of the unit disk.

Let φ6(z)\phi_6\p{z}φ6​(z) be the Möbius transform sending −1↦0-1 \mapsto 0−1↦0, 1↦∞1 \mapsto \infty1↦∞, and i↦ii \mapsto ii↦i, i.e.,

φ6(z)=−z+1z−1.\phi_6\p{z} = -\frac{z + 1}{z - 1}.φ6​(z)=−z−1z+1​.

This maps (−1,1)\p{-1, 1}(−1,1) to (0,∞)\p{0, \infty}(0,∞) and the upper half of the unit circle to (0,i∞)\p{0, i\infty}(0,i∞), so this maps Ω5\Omega_5Ω5​ to Ω6={Im⁡z>0}∩{Re⁡z>0}\Omega_6 = \set{\Im{z} > 0} \cap \set{\Re{z} > 0}Ω6​={Imz>0}∩{Rez>0}. Let φ7(z)=z2\phi_7\p{z} = z^2φ7​(z)=z2, which maps Ω6\Omega_6Ω6​ to Ω7={Im⁡z>0}\Omega_7 = \set{\Im{z} > 0}Ω7​={Imz>0}.

Finally, we can let φ8(z)=z−iz+i\phi_8\p{z} = \frac{z - i}{z + i}φ8​(z)=z+iz−i​, the Cayley transform, which maps the upper half-plane to the unit disk. Hence, φ8∘φ7∘⋯∘φ1\phi_8 \circ \phi_7 \circ \cdots \circ \phi_1φ8​∘φ7​∘⋯∘φ1​ is a conformal mapping from Ω\OmegaΩ to the unit disk.
